hints.content:
One serving of soup is $\redD{11}$ fluid ounces.  

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A graduated cylinder labeled with tick marks from 2 fluid ounces to 18 fluid ounces. Tick marks 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, and 18 fluid ounces are labeled. 1 unlabeled tick mark is shown before 2 fluid ounces, 1 unlabeled tick mark is shown after 18 fluid ounces, and there is 1 unlabeled tick mark between every 2 labeled tick marks. The tomato soup inside the graduated cylinder measures to the unlabeled tick mark above 10 fluid ounces. A line extends from the unlabeled tick mark above 10 fluid ounces and is labeled 11 fluid ounces. !

hints.content:
We can find the number of fluid ounces Soup Shack sold at lunch by multiplying the number of fluid ounces in each serving  $(\redD{11 \text { fluid ounces}})$ by the number of servings sold $(\blueD{{5} \text { servings}})$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two rectangles sit on top of each other. The top rectangle is labeled with a question mark. The bottom rectangle is divided into 5 equal-sized parts. Each part is labeled 11. A curved bracket across the bottom of the rectangle is labeled 5 equal groups. !

hints.content: Soup Shack sold $\greenD{55 \text { fluid ounces}}$ of tomato soup at lunch on Tuesday.

question.content:
Soup Shack sold $5$ servings of tomato soup at lunch on Tuesday.  One serving is shown below.  Each serving of tomato soup had the same number of fluid ounces.
  
[[☃ image 1]]

**How many fluid ounces of tomato soup did Soup Shack sell at lunch on Tuesday?**  

[[☃ input-number 1]] fluid ounces

options.alt: A graduated cylinder labeled with tick marks from 2 fluid ounces to 18 fluid ounces. Tick marks 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, and 18 fluid ounces are labeled. 1 unlabeled tick mark is shown before 2 fluid ounces, 1 unlabeled tick mark is shown after 18 fluid ounces, and there is 1 unlabeled tick mark between every 2 labeled tick marks. The tomato soup inside the graduated cylinder measures to the unlabeled tick mark above 10 fluid ounces. !
